In the 3rd world, most very picky eaters are likely even more undernourished than their peers, and even more susceptible to childhood diseases.  A larger percentage of these kids probably die in early childhood (which is probably also why my parents didn't know other children like this when they were in school in the 1940s - weak children were probably more likely to get and not recover from polio, etc)
Read the comments by the 67 year-old person and the person diagnosed with Asperger's in their 50s.

I'm sure kids in poor countries tend to have a much more monotonous and limited diet which works in the picky eater and anxious prone kid's favor.

Not sure why you would think there weren't pick eaters fifty years ago. Could it be that you weren't in a position to notice parenting concerns and conversations when you were a kid?

I was a picky eater as a kid back then. I remember it drove my parents nuts -- which made me even more anxious. Interestingly, while I remember meal times as often traumatic, my parents don't really remember their frustration with my eating habits.

Despite what you might think, there have always been kids who are more cautious with food. It is to some degree evolutionarily advantageous. Let the tribe take the risks with the strange new food and you are less likely to eat something that will harm you.

I respect the science behind this phenomenon. The only very picky eater I know seems high strung and very sensitive. it makes sense that kids who exhibit this sensitivity will also exhibit it in their future lives.

However, I cannot understand how this is a phenomenon that is so recent and seems to exist in only first-world situations. Do children in poverty in El Salvador or Sri Lanka experience this? In my travelst, I've been exposed the poverty and the eating habits of Central American countries. Could this problem exist there, where 90% of their meals contain the same five ingredients? And why didn't this problem exist fifty years ago when I was a kid?

As I said, I don't doubt the veracity of these findings. But I also cannot ignore that it seems to be present only here and now. Why is that?

As a student in the midst of being introduced to the Common Core Curriculum, I have found that transitioning from the old curriculum, to Common Core has been a struggle. Growing up, I have been accustomed to being instructed precisely what to do, rather than coming to conclusions on my own. It may be thought that Common Core is preparing students for an elite level, however it does not dictate a student's willingness to succeed. Depending on a student's priorities, school can either be very important or meaningless. Nevertheless, a student who is willing to put in hard work is significantly different than a student who is putting off studying. Thus, Common Core can allow a number of students thrive, while a number of students drastically collapse. This is due to the fact that Common Core is harder. Conversely, it is a different story for students with learning dissabilities. Even before Common Core, this group of students had struggled with surviving school. Therefore, Common Core exceeded their capabilities to the extent, leaving them hopeless. Since teachers have been using old methods for a number of years, it can be said that this transition is not an easy one for them either. Although the theory behind Common Core is ideal, the way in which it is executed in schools causes it to be ineffective.
